content.description: Histrionic Personality Disorder (HPD) is characterized by pervasive patterns of excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior. Individuals often feel uncomfortable when not the center of attention and may use appearance, charm, or dramatic expression to gain approval.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A pervasive pattern of excessive emotionality and attention-seeking, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by ≥5 of: (1) Uncomfortable when not the center of attention; (2) Interaction with others often involves inappropriate sexually seductive or provocative behavior; (3) Rapidly shifting and shallow expression of emotions; (4) Consistently uses physical appearance to draw attention; (5) Speech is excessively impressionistic and lacking in detail; (6) Self-dramatization, theatricality, exaggerated emotion; (7) Suggestible (easily influenced by others or circumstances); (8) Considers relationships more intimate than they actually are.
content.prevalence: Estimated 1–2% in the general population; higher rates in clinical populations. Some evidence suggests similar prevalence across genders.
content.age_of_onset: Early adulthood, though attention-seeking traits may appear earlier.
content.prognosis: Chronic course without intervention, though symptoms may diminish with age. Effective treatment can improve relational stability and emotional regulation.

circuitry: Limited neuroimaging data; possible overlaps with emotional regulation networks in the limbic system and prefrontal cortex.
neurochemistry: No specific neurotransmitter abnormalities identified; heightened sensitivity to social rewards may be relevant.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Family studies suggest moderate heritability; often associated with inconsistent parental attention, reinforcement of attention-seeking, or modeling of dramatic behavior.

history_psychosocial: Patterns of attention-seeking, interpersonal relationships, and self-image.
History of dramatic or provocative behavior in social/occupational settings.
medical_assessment: Screen for comorbid mood, anxiety, or substance use disorders.
standardized_measures: Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Personality Disorders (SCID-5-PD).
risk_stratification: Level of interpersonal conflict, occupational instability, and risky behaviors.
evaluation.team_and_process: Psychotherapy-focused approach; may involve couples or group therapy for interpersonal skill-building.

severity_levels.mild: Occasional attention-seeking behaviors with moderate interpersonal impact.
severity_levels.moderate: Frequent dramatic or provocative behavior causing significant relationship or work disruption.
severity_levels.severe: Persistent, intense attention-seeking with high interpersonal conflict, exploitation risk, and occupational instability.

biological: Genetic predisposition to high extraversion and emotional reactivity
psychological: Low self-esteem masked by dramatic behavior

impact_on_life.school_work: Difficulty maintaining focus on tasks without recognition; conflict with peers or authority due to dramatic style.
impact_on_life.social: Superficial relationships; frequent conflict or instability.
impact_on_life.medical: Potential for risky behaviors that endanger health.
impact_on_life.emotional: Vulnerability to rejection and dependency on external validation.

psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) to increase self-awareness and reduce maladaptive attention-seeking.
Psychodynamic therapy to address unconscious needs and interpersonal patterns.
Interpersonal therapy to improve relationship quality.
medications: No specific pharmacologic treatment; medications may target comorbid depression or anxiety.
lifestyle_interventions: Mindfulness training to increase emotional regulation.
Building non-appearance-based self-esteem through skills and achievements.
care_coordination: Involvement of support systems to reinforce healthy behaviors.

treatment_goals: Develop stable self-esteem not reliant on external attention.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Underrecognition in individuals whose appearance conforms to cultural norms.
overdiagnosis_factors: Confusing short-term dramatic reactions to stress with chronic personality traits.
warning_signs: Escalating provocative or risky behaviors to gain attention
self_help_strategies: Engage in activities that provide fulfillment without needing external validation.
Practice reflective listening and focus on others’ needs.

adolescence: Attention-seeking through style, speech, or peer group behavior; difficulty tolerating not being the center of attention.
adulthood: Persistent pattern of dramatic, approval-seeking behaviors impacting relationships and work.

real_life_examples: A 30-year-old who changes jobs frequently due to interpersonal drama begins CBT and learns to manage attention-seeking urges, improving stability.
A 25-year-old who dresses provocatively to gain attention in social settings works with a therapist to build self-worth through skills and interests.
content.when_to_seek_help: When attention-seeking behaviors cause repeated relationship or occupational problems, or lead to risky situations.

challenging_factors: High suggestibility leading to inconsistent treatment adherence
Comorbid mood or substance use disorders
